awd_titl_txt: Photochromic Switching for Nanostructured Polymer Gels
awd_abstract_narration:
Controlling the shape and arrangement of materials at sizes roughly a thousandth of the thickness of a human hair is a much sought after capability in advanced manufacturing. The only commercial instrument capable of controlling the shape and arrangement of these nanometer-sized materials is both expensive (~$50 million) and prohibitively slow due to their requirement for use on flat surfaces. A potentially transformative alternate method that is not subject to these severe constraints is hampered by a lack of understanding of the chemistry involved in the synthesis of the materials. The paucity of knowledge on these syntheses is targeted by studying and controlling the speeds at which the relevant chemical reactions occur. Additionally, this project educates participating graduate and undergraduate students in state of the art chemistry techniques. K-8 students are inspired to consider careers in science and engineering while working with their families on research-themed. household material-based activities that are available through a widely accessible online portal.

The central aim of this project is to develop a fundamental understanding of the underlying chemical kinetics needed to enable 3-dimensional interference lithography with a resolution beyond the diffraction barrier. The key requirement is a reversible and saturable reaction accompanied by a material-writing step. Reaction rates are controlled by manipulating the steric and electronic nature of substituents on the monomer, and tailoring the chemical structures of the other key active components (e.g., polymers and crosslinking agents). The objectives of this research include the synthesis of a combinatorial library of monomer derivatives with systematically varied steric and electronic properties; quantification of the kinetics of nanometer-sized material growth, with the goal of obtaining rapid and saturable equilibrium under low laser intensities; and polymerization of diffraction unlimited features over large areas.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project resulted in a fundamental advance in the scientific and engineering understanding of controlling the shape and arrangement of materials at sizes roughly a thousandth of the thickness of a human hair. This broad area is a crucial capability in advanced manufacturing, particularly in the semiconductor industry. The dominant commercial instrument capable of practically producing such small (nanoscale) features over areas greater than a square millimeter is currently prohibitively expensive (order of 50M$). The primary intellectual merit outcome of this project is the proof of principle demonstration of a new process by which the same size fidelity can be achieved over large area surfaces while using visible light, which can significantly reduce costs. This capability is enabled by the use of a switchable molecule known as spirothiopyran. Specific advances include the invention of a spirothiopyran based light sensitive material in which patterns are written with one color or light and erased using another color before the final structure is formed; the understanding of the impact of local environment on the switching behavior of the photo-switchable molecule; the demonstration of exceptional resolutions in molecularly thin films over large areas while using visible light; and the creation of a model that captures the complex interactions of the light and chemical concentration fields as a function of time. These important advances have been disseminated to the public in the form of 4 peer reviewed publications, as well as several conference talks. The broader impact outcomes are related to promoting chemistry, physics and materials engineering as career options to K-12 students, with an emphasis on groups that are traditionally underrepresented in these fields. These broader impact outcomes were achieved by conducting hands on learning workshops, both in person and through online modalities.

 


Last Modified: 12/15/2021
Modified by: Chaitanya Ullal
